posts.name: Danielle
posts.cooked: We were given a BringSmart 1rpm motor and I was wondering if it is legal to use on our robot? I‚Äôve looked through the game manual but am unsure if it‚Äôs allowed. We‚Äôve only used the motors from AndyMark before but would like to try something new. Thank you

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked: If it is not in the allowed motor list in the rules, it is not allowed.

R501 is your friend. In this case, I‚Äôm 99% sure that is not on the allowed motor list, and additionally if it is, it is probably a bad idea. Brushless motors such as the NEO 1.0, 1.1, 550 and vortex, as well as the kraken x60, x44 and also the CTRE minion are solid bets for motors this year. Failing that, CIMs or 775s are your friends.

if it not in the legal devices I would be safe and not use it but bring it to a event and ask since we have had this happen to us we had a motor that wasn‚Äôt on the list but it was similar to it so we got the green light

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
thegravitor:

we had a motor that wasn‚Äôt on the list but it was similar to it so we got the green light

That is what is generally termed ‚Äúhighly problematic‚Äù. There‚Äôs a motor-gearbox series from AM that might fit that category, but it‚Äôs called out in R501 that this part number series all uses the same LEGAL motor and thus is all legal.

I would not bring an illegal motor to competition, at all. If I wasn‚Äôt sure I‚Äôd put pictures up on CD and ping Al and Chuck, the Global LRIs, for feedback.

typically yes but we weren‚Äôt using it that year anyway so we thought why not ask someone who would actually know and be able to tell us if we wanted to use it in the future the motor was just a cim but shorter

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
thegravitor:

the motor was just a cim but shorter

Sounds like a MiniCIM, which is still on the Legal list. Should have been a part number check.
pretty much but are worry was it was made by a in town manufacturer and we got more than 20 of them donated

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
Oh.

Yeah‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs right out for competition use, end of discussion. The motors must be of the specific part numbers. Whichever inspector or LRI said it was OK was highly incorrect, and needs to be forced to count and test throttle motors for a while.

posts.name: James Lyon
posts.cooked: They really let you in with local made motors?

posts.name: Matthew K
posts.cooked:
DanieH:

the motors from AndyMark before

out of curiosity, which motors from AndyMark? Also, what are you using to power your drivetrain?

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
Depending on the opinion of an RI at one event regarding the legality of a part or construction technique is a dangerous practice.

Over the last two year at our District Champs, we have encountered quite a number of robots with illegal items where the robot had ‚Äúpassed inspection‚Äù at two prior District Events. Some were clearly, non-negotiable, illegal items like stickers on pneumatic tanks or bumper sets that exceeded the weight limits by over a pound.

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
DanieH:

BringSmart 1rpm

No.  But also, without a link to the exact part, this might be an AC motor, meant to be connected to a wall outlet (based on a very quick/shallow search).  And, 1 RPM is really slow.
we didn‚Äôt use them since they weren‚Äôt on the list but got told they have no issue in us using them

posts.name: Matt Golman
posts.cooked:
The person who gave you the green light was a Lead Robot Inspector? A trained and experienced volunteer told you that it was okay to use a motor that wasn‚Äôt on the approved motors list?

That‚Äôs‚Ä¶ negligent. What event was this?
it was 2019 so its been a good while so I‚Äôm not 100 percent sure on event but it was a lead sine they had to go get him to make sure

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
thegravitor:

if it not in the legal devices I would be safe and not use it but bring it to a event and ask since we have had this happen to us we had a motor that wasn‚Äôt on the list but it was similar to it so we got the green light

There have been years where the rules allowed things like ‚ÄúAutomotive Motors‚Äù that run at under a certain current, so it allowed some flexibility, however I see no such exception like that this year.

I have also been to events where teams had motors on their robots that were clearly not legal and a first-time inspector passed the robot anyways since they didn‚Äôt know any better, resulting in a later follow-up from the LRI and the team having to rip off the motor and replace it in the middle of the event.

If your motor is not explicitly on the allowed motors list with a matching part number or in one of the following exceptions, please DO NOT bring it, the rules do not allow for ‚Äúsimilar‚Äù motors:

From R501: Fans, no greater than 120mm (nominal) size and rated electrical input power no greater than 10 watts (W) continuous duty at 12 volts (VDC)

Hard drive motors part of a legal COTS computing device

Factory installed vibration and autofocus motors resident in COTS computing devices (e.g. rumble motor in a smartphone).

PWM COTS rotational servos with stall current ‚â§ 4A and mechanical output power ‚â§ 8W at 6V. PWM COTS linear servos with max stall current ‚â§ 1A at 6V.

Motors integral to a COTS sensor (e.g. LIDAR, scanning sonar, etc.), provided the device is not modified except to facilitate mounting

1 compressor compliant with R806 and used to compress air for the ROBOT‚ÄôS pneumatic system

COTS linear actuators, electrical solenoid actuators, or electromagnets rated for 12V and wired downstream of a breaker 20A or less. Electrical solenoid actuators or electromagnets used at 24V must be rated for 24V.

In your case since you said these resembled MiniCIMs the robot inspectors may have assumed they were MiniCIMs without looking at the part number. The issue with this is you can have two motors that appear identical but have completely different performance characteristics on the inside. Use those motors all you want for off-season projects or prototypes, but I‚Äôd keep them off the competition bot.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
Given your team number, year, TBA , and Google Maps, it‚Äôs either Wake Forest or Pembroke District events, the former being more likely (closer to your site and earlier in the season).

@Al_Skierkiewicz @ChuckDickerson something to remind the LRIs about during training, I think, if you get time to spare from going over the bumper rules with them.

cbale2000:

There have been years where the rules allowed things like ‚ÄúAutomotive Motors‚Äù that run at under a certain current, so it allowed some flexibility, however I see no such exception like that this year.

Had someone try that in 2020‚ÄìI caught it pre-event and they were able to swap the motor of the mechanism out within a week. It was an oversight due to lack of recent history, in that team‚Äôs case‚Äìthey thought that was still a thing. The re-motored mechanism got them Creativity.

posts.name: Al Skierkiewicz  Learn Something New, Every Day!
posts.cooked: Sorry, but that motor does not appear in the allowed list.  There has never been a 1 rpm motor that was legal that i can remember. There were a few years where automotive motors were allowed but the team had to prove they bought them at automotive outlets and what they were used for.  That provision has been dropped.  The hope had been that teams would get additional sponsorship from junk dealers in their area.  It never worked out that way so the rule was dropped. On occasion, when 550 DC motors were allowed, 550 motors were allowed from other manufacturers.  Post a picture of the motor and we will see if it might be useful in  the future.
posts.display_username: Al Skierkiewicz  Learn Something New, Every Day!
